title: Regulatory Compliance
subtitle: FDA & CE Mark Approval Pathways for AI/ML Medical Devices
tooltipContent: This section outlines the regulatory pathways for AI-based medical devices in the US (FDA) and Europe (CE Mark). Understanding these requirements is essential for commercializing medical AI software.
disclaimer: This application is currently for research and educational purposes only. It is NOT FDA-approved or CE-marked as a medical device. This information is provided for educational purposes about regulatory pathways.
fdaTooltip: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates medical devices in the United States through various pathways depending on risk classification and device type.
classIIDescription: AI-based skin lesion analysis systems typically fall under Class II, requiring 510(k) premarket notification and demonstration of substantial equivalence to a predicate device.
step1Description: Identify legally marketed device with similar intended use and technological characteristics
step2Description: Conduct clinical studies demonstrating safety and effectiveness (typically 100-200+ patients)
step3Description: Provide software validation per FDA guidance (IEC 62304, cybersecurity, algorithm transparency)
step4Description: Submit comprehensive documentation including clinical data, software validation, and labeling
step5Description: FDA review typically takes 90 days (may require additional information requests)
keyFDARequirements: Key FDA Requirements for AI/ML Devices
requirement1: Clinical validation with diagnostic accuracy metrics (sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV)
requirement3: Training data documentation (sources, diversity, bias mitigation)
requirement6: Post-market surveillance plan for model performance monitoring
requirement7: Quality System Regulation (QSR) compliance (21 CFR Part 820)
ceMarkTooltip: The CE Mark is required for medical devices sold in the European Union. The Medical Device Regulation (MDR) 2017/745 governs AI-based medical software.
mdrDescription: Under MDR 2017/745, AI software for diagnosis typically qualifies as Class IIa (supporting diagnosis) or Class IIb (influencing patient management decisions). Classification depends on intended use and risk level.
ceStep1Description: Apply MDR classification rules (especially Rule 11 for software)
ceStep2Description: Engage EU-recognized Notified Body for conformity assessment (required for Class IIa/IIb)
ceStep3Description: Prepare comprehensive technical file per MDR Annex II and III
ceStep4Description: Conduct clinical evaluation per MDR Annex XIV (clinical data required)
ceStep6Description: Issue DoC and affix CE mark after Notified Body approval
keyMDRRequirements: Key MDR Requirements for AI/ML Devices
mdrReq1: Clinical evaluation report with clinical data
aimlTooltip: AI and machine learning medical devices have unique regulatory considerations including algorithm transparency, continuous learning, and bias mitigation.
transparency1: Detailed description of algorithm architecture and training methodology
transparency2: Training dataset characteristics (size, diversity, demographics, sources)
transparency3: Explainability features (e.g., Grad-CAM heatmaps, attention maps)
transparency4: Performance metrics across different patient populations
learningDescription: FDA's "Predetermined Change Control Plan" allows certain algorithm modifications without new 510(k) submission. Requirements include:
learning1: Pre-specified modification protocol in original submission
bias1: Performance evaluation across demographic groups (age, sex, race, skin type)
bias4: Ongoing bias monitoring in post-market surveillance
fdaGuidanceLink: FDA.gov - Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning Software as Medical Device
guidanceLink: Good Machine Learning Practice for Medical Device Development (FDA, Health Canada, MHRA)
